subsubsection.title: The Definition

definition.title: Continuity
definition.p: A function is continuous at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)
If this condition fails, then f is said to be discontinuous at input a.
f is continuous on an interval if it is continuous at every number in the interval.

assemblage.title: Conditions for Continuity
assemblage.p:
Continuity of a function requires three things:
a is in the domain of f
\ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) exists
\ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)

question.statement: Look back at Section 1.5 and the conditions for the existence of a limit. What connections can you draw between the existence of a limit and the conditions for continuity?
question.solution: In order for a function to be continuous, the limit must exist.

assemblage.title: Types of Discontinuities
assemblage.p:

subsubsection.definition: Continuity from the Right and Left Continuity (Right and Left) A function f is said to be continuous from the right at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a^+} f(x) = f(a), and f is continuous from the left at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x) = f(a).

Discontinuous at x = 5

Show that [\![x]\!] is right-continuous, but not left-continuous at integer values.
example.solution: Let x=a be any integer. For right continuity, we need to show that \ds \lim_{x\to a^+} = f(a). Note that \ds \lim_{x\to a^+} f(x) = a, and that f(a) = a. Thus, the function is right continuous. Similarly, for left continuity, we require \ds \lim_{x\to a^-} = f(a). However, \ds \lim_{x\to a^-} = a-1 and f(a) = a; thus, the function is not left continuous.

example.statement: Show that the function f(x) = 3+\sqrt{1-x^2} is continuous on the interval [-1,1].

solution.p: We prove the claim in three steps: (1) show continuity at the left endpoint; (2) show continuity at the right endpoint; (3) show continuity on the interval (-1,1).

For continuity at x=-1, we need to show right continuity of the function at the point. For this to be true, \ds \lim_{x\to -1^+} = f(-1). Then, \ds \lim_{x\to -1^+} f(x)= \lim_{x\to -1^+} 3 + \sqrt{1-x^2} = 3 Since f(-1) = 3, the function is right continuous.

For continuity at x=1, we need to show left continuity of the function at the point. For this to be true, \ds \lim_{x\to 1} = f(1). Then, \ds \lim_{x\to 1^-} f(x)= \lim_{x\to 1^-} 3 + \sqrt{1-x^2} = 3 Since f(1) = 3, the function is left continuous.

theorem.title: Properties of Continuous Functions
theorem.statement:
If f and g are continuous at a, and if c is a constant, then the following functions are all continuous at a:
f\pm g
cf
fg
\dfrac{f}{g}, for g\neq 0
f\circ g

example.statement: Prove the first property of continuous functions.
example.solution: We want to show that \ds \lim_{x\to a}[f(x) \pm g(x)] = f(a) \pm g(a). Since f(x) and g(x) are continuous, we know that \ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a) and \ds \lim_{x\to a} g(x) = g(a). Then, \ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) \pm \lim_{x\to a} g(x) = f(a) + g(a) By the sum/difference limit law from Section 1.6, we can rewrite the left hand side as \ds \lim_{x\to a} [f(x) \pm g(x)] = f(a) + g(a) Which is what we wanted to show.

question.statement: Can you prove the remaining 4 properties?
question.solution: The proofs run similarly to the previous Example 1.8.11, utilizing limit laws from Section 1.6.

subsubsection.title: The Intermediate Value Theorem

theorem.title: Intermediate Value Theorem
theorem.p: Suppose that f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b], and let N be any number between f(a) and f(b), where f(a)\neq f(b). Then, there exists a number c in (a,b) such that f(c) = N.

example.statement: Show that the equation 4x^3-6x^2+3x-2 = 0 has a root between 1 and 2.

solution.p: Our strategy will be to (1) show that the IVT is applicable, and (2) show that the function switches from positive to negative. Because of continuity (and the images above), the function must pass through 0 at least once.
First, note that the IVT is applicable since f(x) = 4x^3-6x^2+3x-2 is continuous as a polynomial.
Now, let N = 0. To show that f(x) = 0, we must know we pass through 0, i.e. we switch from positive to negative. Note that f(0) = -2 and f(2) = 12, so we have our condition met.
Since f(0) = -2 and f(2) = 12, by the IVT, we know that there exists at least one c\in (0,2) such that f(c) = 0.

example.statement:
Find values of a and b that make f continuous everywhere.
f(x) = \begin{cases}\dfrac{x^2-4}{x-2} \amp x \lt 2 \\ ax^2 - bx + 3 \amp 2\leq x \lt 3 \\ 2x - a + b \amp x \geq 3 \end{cases}
Suppose f and g are continuous function such that g(2) = 6 and \ds \lim_{x\to 2} [3f(x) + f(x)g(x)] = 36. What is f(2)?
Show that the equation \sqrt{x-5} = \dfrac{1}{x+3} has at least one real root.
example.solution: Set f(x) = \sqrt{x-5}-\dfrac{1}{x+3}. f(x) is continuous on [5,\infty), so its root (if it exists) must occur on that interval. Since f(5) = -\dfrac{1}{8} and f(6) = \dfrac{8}{9}, the function switches from positive to negative on (5,6). Since it is continuous on that interval, we may conclude that f(x) = 0 at least once in (5,6) by the IVT. Thus, the function has at least one real root.
